fields.author: Walter Smith
fields.raw_text:
This is a happy day for me, to have now a page where I can simply set down the occasional wonderful sentence that I’ve come across while reading. Pithy sentences that capture in just a few words some thought or essence, or that make you smile out loud, as it were. And here, on my birthday, is the page as a gift from my son Conor. Thank you, Conor. I hope that if anyone sees this page, that they share their own favorite moments in Reading as well. Someone once said to me, meaning to criticize, "How can you re-read a book you've already read?" He couldn't understand the pleasure taken in good writing. The turn of a phrase, the ability to distill perfectly a place, an emotion, our human foibles, to make us weep and laugh in the same sentence. I asked him why he read poetry. Surely he'd read those poems before? Or why listen to that sonata again? You've heard it a hundred times. A glimmer began to appear.... So, to those whose glimmer has always been a glowing light, and to Conor, this site is dedicated.

There's nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and open a vein.

—Walter Smith The Bloody Typewriter 1954
fields.text: There's nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and open a vein.

fields.author: Walter Smith
fields.raw_text:
This is a happy day for me, to have now a page where I can simply set down the occasional wonderful sentence that I’ve come across while reading. Pithy sentences that capture in just a few words some thought or essence, or that make you smile out loud, as it were. And here, on my birthday, is the page as a gift from my son Conor. Thank you, Conor. I hope that if anyone sees this page, that they share their own favorite moments in Reading as well. Someone once said to me, meaning to criticize, "How can you re-read a book you've already read?" He couldn't understand the pleasure taken in good writing. The turn of a phrase, the ability to distill perfectly a place, an emotion, our human foibles, to make us weep and laugh in the same sentence. I asked him why he read poetry. Surely he'd read those poems before? Or why listen to that sonata again? You've heard it a hundred times. A glimmer began to appear.... So, to those whose glimmer has always been a glowing light, and to Conor, this site is dedicated.

There's nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and open a vein.

—Walter Smith The Bloody Typewriter 1954
fields.text: There's nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and open a vein.

fields.author: Leo Tolstoy
fields.raw_text:
The first room, with a large, dilapidated stove and two dirty windows, has a black measure for measuring the prisoners in one corner, and in another corner hung a large image of Christ, as is usual in places where they torture people.

—Leo Tolstoy Resurrection 1899
fields.text: The first room, with a large, dilapidated stove and two dirty windows, has a black measure for measuring the prisoners in one corner, and in another corner hung a large image of Christ, as is usual in places where they torture people.

fields.author: Charles Kightly
fields.raw_text:
Manure your garden: and marry if you dare.

—Charles Kightly The Perpetual Almanack of Folklore 1987
fields.text: Manure your garden: and marry if you dare.

fields.author: Wilkie Collins
fields.raw_text:
I am (thank God!) constitutionally superior to reason.

—Wilkie Collins The Moonstone 1868
fields.text: I am (thank God!) constitutionally superior to reason.

fields.author: Agatha Christie
fields.raw_text:
Miss Cynthia was a nigger once, and oh, the trouble she had.

—Agatha Christie The Mysterious Affair at Styles 1920
fields.text: Miss Cynthia was a nigger once, and oh, the trouble she had.

fields.author: Terry Pratchett
fields.raw_text:
Getting an education was a bit like a communicable sexual disease. It made you unsuitable for a lot of jobs and then you had the urge to pass it on.

—Terry Pratchett Hogfather 1996
fields.text: Getting an education was a bit like a communicable sexual disease. It made you unsuitable for a lot of jobs and then you had the urge to pass it on.

fields.author: J. Sheridan Le Fanu
fields.raw_text:
[He] was a gentleman and an officer, and of course an honourable man; but somehow I should not have liked to buy a horse from him.

—J. Sheridan Le Fanu Wylder's Hand 1864
fields.text: [He] was a gentleman and an officer, and of course an honourable man; but somehow I should not have liked to buy a horse from him.

fields.author: Émile Gaboriau
fields.raw_text:
From this moment I hate and despise him.  Tell him I am willing to be his wife.

—Émile Gaboriau Within an Inch of His Life 1873
fields.text: From this moment I hate and despise him.  Tell him I am willing to be his wife.
fields.source: Within an Inch of His Life

fields.author: Paul of Tarsus
fields.raw_text:
Beloved, never avenge yourselves...if your enemy is hungry, feed him; if he is thirsty, give him a drink; for by so doing you will heap burning coals upon his head.

—Paul of Tarsus The Epistle to the Romans 12:19-20 50's
fields.text: Beloved, never avenge yourselves...if your enemy is hungry, feed him; if he is thirsty, give him a drink; for by so doing you will heap burning coals upon his head.

fields.author: Wilkie Collins
fields.raw_text:
He submitted to the force of events as a cabbage-leaf submits to the teeth of a rabbit.

—Wilkie Collins Heart and Science 1883
fields.text: He submitted to the force of events as a cabbage-leaf submits to the teeth of a rabbit.

fields.author: Edith Œnone Somerville & Martin Ross
fields.raw_text:
An enterprising advertiser asks, "What is more terrible than war?" We answer unhesitatingly, oranges in the hands of young children.

—Edith Œnone Somerville & Martin Ross Through Connemara in a Governess-Cart 1893
fields.text: An enterprising advertiser asks, "What is more terrible than war?" We answer unhesitatingly, oranges in the hands of young children.

fields.author: Émile Gaboriau
fields.raw_text:
As long as we have a spark of commonsense left, we are not really in love.

—Émile Gaboriau The Clique of Gold 1871
fields.text: As long as we have a spark of commonsense left, we are not really in love.

fields.author: James Lee Burke
fields.raw_text:
If I harmed you in any way,...I regret not doing a whole lot more of it.

—James Lee Burke The Glass Rainbow 2010
fields.text: If I harmed you in any way,...I regret not doing a whole lot more of it.

fields.author: W.F. Harvey
fields.raw_text:
It was arranged on the plan of many college libraries, with tall, projecting bookcases forming deep recesses of dusty silence, fit graves for the old hates of forgotten controversy, the dead passions of forgotten lives.

—W.F. Harvey The Beast with Five Fingers 1919
fields.text: It was arranged on the plan of many college libraries, with tall, projecting bookcases forming deep recesses of dusty silence, fit graves for the old hates of forgotten controversy, the dead passions of forgotten lives.

fields.author: George R. R. Martin
fields.raw_text:
We're all just songs in the end.  If we are lucky.

—George R. R. Martin A Storm of Swords 2000
fields.text: We're all just songs in the end.  If we are lucky.

fields.author: Tom Crean
fields.raw_text:
God gives us the tools and the courage, but we have to do the work ourselves.

—Tom Crean Indiana University Basketball Coach 2012
fields.text: God gives us the tools and the courage, but we have to do the work ourselves.

fields.author: Anonymous
fields.raw_text:
St. Patrick was a gentleman

Who through strategy and stealth

Drove all the snakes from Ireland,

Here's toasting to his health;

But not too many toastings

Lest you lose yourself and then

Forget the good St. Patrick

And see all those snakes again.

—Anonymous Irish Toasts, edited by Karen Bailey 1996
fields.text: St. Patrick was a gentleman
fields.source: Irish Toasts, edited by Karen Bailey

fields.raw_text:
At nine years old, Christian was a little rag of a girl; a rag, but imbued with the spirit of the rag that is nailed to the mast, and flaunts, unconquered, until it is shot away.

—Edith Œnone Somerville & Martin Ross

Mount Music 1919

fields.author: Arthur J. Rees
fields.raw_text:
Barrant reflected that women resembled horses in value.  The mettlesome showy ones were bred to display their paces for rich men only.  Serviceable hacks, warranted to work a lifetime, could not be expected to be ornamental as well as useful.  So long as they pulled their burdens without jibbing overmuch, one had to be content.

—Arthur J. Rees The Moon Rock 1922
fields.text: Barrant reflected that women resembled horses in value.  The mettlesome showy ones were bred to display their paces for rich men only.  Serviceable hacks, warranted to work a lifetime, could not be expected to be ornamental as well as useful.  So long as they pulled their burdens without jibbing overmuch, one had to be content.

fields.author: Jeremiah (?)
fields.raw_text:
The LORD said to the prophet Elijah, "Have you noticed how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Since he has done this, I will not bring disaster on him during his lifetime; it will be during his son's lifetime that I will bring disaster on Ahab's family."

—Jeremiah (?) I Kings 21:29 6th c. BC
fields.text: The LORD said to the prophet Elijah, "Have you noticed how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Since he has done this, I will not bring disaster on him during his lifetime; it will be during his son's lifetime that I will bring disaster on Ahab's family."

fields.author: Ernest Bramah
fields.raw_text:
It has been said there are few situations in life that cannot be honourably settled, and without loss of time, either by suicide, a bag of gold, or by thrusting a despised antagonist over the edge of a precipice upon a dark night.

—Ernest Bramah Kai Lung's Golden Hours 1922
fields.text: It has been said there are few situations in life that cannot be honourably settled, and without loss of time, either by suicide, a bag of gold, or by thrusting a despised antagonist over the edge of a precipice upon a dark night.

fields.author: Samuel Johnson
fields.raw_text:
Allow children to be happy in their own way, for what better way will they find?

Samuel Johnson 1709-1784
fields.text: Allow children to be happy in their own way, for what better way will they find?

fields.author: Charles Dickens
fields.raw_text:
I don’t ask you for your love; give me yourself and your hatred; give me yourself and that pretty rage; give me yourself and that enchanting scorn; it will be enough for me.

—Charles Dickens The Mystery of Edwin Drood 1870
fields.text: I don’t ask you for your love; give me yourself and your hatred; give me yourself and that pretty rage; give me yourself and that enchanting scorn; it will be enough for me.

fields.author: Ivan Turgenev
fields.raw_text:
I was then five-and-twenty, - that was a sufficient indication that I had a past....

—Ivan Turgenev Annouchka, A Tale 1884
fields.text: I was then five-and-twenty, - that was a sufficient indication that I had a past....

fields.author: Charles Dickens
fields.raw_text:
For, Evil often stops short at itself and dies with the doer of it; but Good, never.

—Charles Dickens Our Mutual Friend 1864
fields.text: For, Evil often stops short at itself and dies with the doer of it; but Good, never.

fields.author: J. Sheridan LeFanu
fields.raw_text:
If there be courage and mental activity, and no conscience, we have a very dangerous devil.

—J. Sheridan LeFanu Willing to Die 1872
fields.text: If there be courage and mental activity, and no conscience, we have a very dangerous devil.

fields.author: Charles Dickens
fields.raw_text:
There is something indefinably keen and wan about her anatomy, and she has a watchful way of looking out of the corners of her eyes without turning her head which could be pleasantly dispensed with, especially when she is in an ill humour and near knives.

—Charles Dickens Bleak House 1852
fields.text: There is something indefinably keen and wan about her anatomy, and she has a watchful way of looking out of the corners of her eyes without turning her head which could be pleasantly dispensed with, especially when she is in an ill humour and near knives.

fields.author: James Bowker, F.R.G.S.I.
fields.raw_text:
The darker forms of superstition, like lower organisms, are more tenacious of life....

—James Bowker, F.R.G.S.I. Goblin Tales of Lancashire 1883
fields.text: The darker forms of superstition, like lower organisms, are more tenacious of life....

fields.author: Anthony Trollope
fields.raw_text:
...but after all, it is only prettiness that requires a dimple:  full-blown beauty wants no such adventitious aid.

—Anthony Trollope The Bertrams 1859
fields.text: ...but after all, it is only prettiness that requires a dimple:  full-blown beauty wants no such adventitious aid.

fields.author: Elizabeth Gaskell
fields.raw_text:
one thing I am clear and sure about is this that Jesus Christ was not equal to His father.

—Elizabeth Gaskell from a letter to her daughter Marianne (1810-1865)
fields.text: one thing I am clear and sure about is this that Jesus Christ was not equal to His father.
fields.source: from a letter to her daughter Marianne

fields.author: Anthony Trollope
fields.raw_text:
How tenfold sorrowful are our sorrows when borne in solitude!

—Anthony Trollope The Bertrams 1859
fields.text: How tenfold sorrowful are our sorrows when borne in solitude!

fields.author: G.K. Chesterton
fields.raw_text:
"I don't know," he said, "that I have any particular objection in detail to your excellent scheme of Government.  My only objection is a quite personal one. It is, that if I were asked whether I would belong to it, I should ask first of all, if I was not permitted, as an alternative, to be a toad in a ditch."

—G.K. Chesterton The Napoleon of Notting Hill 1904
fields.text: "I don't know," he said, "that I have any particular objection in detail to your excellent scheme of Government.  My only objection is a quite personal one. It is, that if I were asked whether I would belong to it, I should ask first of all, if I was not permitted, as an alternative, to be a toad in a ditch."

fields.author: Anthony Trollope
fields.raw_text:
but gardeners, as a class, are a profane people.

—Anthony Trollope The Belton Estate 1866
fields.text: but gardeners, as a class, are a profane people.

fields.author: Anthony Trollope
fields.raw_text:
The horse is a closely sympathetic beast, and will make his turns, and do his trottings, and comport himself generally in strict unison with the pulsations of his master's heart.  When a horse won't jump it is generally the case that the inner man is declining to jump also, let the outer man seem ever so anxious to accomplish the feat.

—Anthony Trollope The Belton Estate 1866
fields.text: The horse is a closely sympathetic beast, and will make his turns, and do his trottings, and comport himself generally in strict unison with the pulsations of his master's heart.  When a horse won't jump it is generally the case that the inner man is declining to jump also, let the outer man seem ever so anxious to accomplish the feat.

fields.author: Richard Marsh
fields.raw_text:
That [he] was one of those...which are apt to exercise an uncanny influence over the weak and the foolish folk with whom they come in contact, - the kind of creature for whom it is always just as well to keep a seasoned rope close handy.

—Richard Marsh The Beetle: A Mystery 1897
fields.text: That [he] was one of those...which are apt to exercise an uncanny influence over the weak and the foolish folk with whom they come in contact, - the kind of creature for whom it is always just as well to keep a seasoned rope close handy.

fields.author: Emile Gaboriau
fields.raw_text:
She will become famous.  What shame and misery!

—Emile Gaboriau L'Affaire Lerouge 1866
fields.text: She will become famous.  What shame and misery!

fields.author: Ellen Wood
fields.raw_text:
The two words, 'Hope on,' are ever beating to and fro in my brain, like the tickings of that clock, and sometimes I persuade myself that the time-piece says, 'Hope on, hope on.'

—Ellen Wood It May Be True 1865
fields.text: The two words, 'Hope on,' are ever beating to and fro in my brain, like the tickings of that clock, and sometimes I persuade myself that the time-piece says, 'Hope on, hope on.'

fields.author: Theodore Sturgeon
fields.raw_text:
He always had time—time to talk and to read, time to wonder quietly, time to listen to those who valued his listening, time to rephrase his pedantries for those who found them arduous in the original.

—Theodore Sturgeon More Than Human 1953
fields.text: He always had time—time to talk and to read, time to wonder quietly, time to listen to those who valued his listening, time to rephrase his pedantries for those who found them arduous in the original.

fields.author: J. Meade Falkner
fields.raw_text:
...we should never, I say, revile Fortune, for just at that moment when she appears to have deserted us, she may be only gone away to seek some richest treasure to bring back with her.

—J. Meade Falkner Moonfleet 1898
fields.text: ...we should never, I say, revile Fortune, for just at that moment when she appears to have deserted us, she may be only gone away to seek some richest treasure to bring back with her.

fields.author: Joseph Sheridan Le Fanu
fields.raw_text:
I tell you, sirrah, I have been in love, and I have been jilted - jilted, sir! and when I was jilted, I thought the jilting itself quite enough, without improving the matter by getting myself buried, dead or alive.

— Joseph Sheridan Le Fanu The Cock and Anchor 1895
fields.text: I tell you, sirrah, I have been in love, and I have been jilted - jilted, sir! and when I was jilted, I thought the jilting itself quite enough, without improving the matter by getting myself buried, dead or alive.

fields.author: John Meade Falkner
fields.raw_text:
How weary she would find it to walk alone down the long paths of old age! how hard it was to be deprived of a dear arm on whose support she had reckoned for when "the slow dark hours begin"!

—John Meade Falkner The Nebuly Coat 1903
fields.text: How weary she would find it to walk alone down the long paths of old age! how hard it was to be deprived of a dear arm on whose support she had reckoned for when "the slow dark hours begin"!

fields.author: George MacDonald
fields.raw_text:
I am an old bachelor; not very far from fifty, in fact; old enough, at all events, to be able to take pleasure in watching without sharing; yet ready, notwithstanding, when occasion offers, to take any necessary pat in what may be going on, I am able, as it were, to sit quietly alone, and look down upon life from a second-floor window, delighting myself with my own speculations...yet...I am not the last to rush down stairs and into the street, upon occasion....

—George MacDonald Adela Cathcart 1864
fields.text: I am an old bachelor; not very far from fifty, in fact; old enough, at all events, to be able to take pleasure in watching without sharing; yet ready, notwithstanding, when occasion offers, to take any necessary pat in what may be going on, I am able, as it were, to sit quietly alone, and look down upon life from a second-floor window, delighting myself with my own speculations...yet...I am not the last to rush down stairs and into the street, upon occasion....

fields.author: George MacDonald
fields.raw_text:
But existence is an awful grandeur and delight.

—George MacDonald Adela Cathcart 1864
fields.text: But existence is an awful grandeur and delight.

fields.author: Olaf Stapledon
fields.raw_text:
His researches into the world of men had been too devastating for a mind which, though superior in quality, was immature and delicate. But the wild had cleansed him, healed him, brought him to sanity again. He could now put /Homo sapiens/ at arm's length for study and appreciation. And he saw that, though no divinity, the creature was after all a noble and even a lovable beast, indeed the noblest and most lovable of them all; nay further, that its very repulsiveness lay in its being something more than beast, but not enough more. A normal human being, he now ungrudgingly admitted, was indeed a spirit of a higher order than any beast, though in the main obtuse, heartless, unfaithful to the best in himself.

—Olaf Stapledon Odd John 1935
fields.text: His researches into the world of men had been too devastating for a mind which, though superior in quality, was immature and delicate. But the wild had cleansed him, healed him, brought him to sanity again. He could now put /Homo sapiens/ at arm's length for study and appreciation. And he saw that, though no divinity, the creature was after all a noble and even a lovable beast, indeed the noblest and most lovable of them all; nay further, that its very repulsiveness lay in its being something more than beast, but not enough more. A normal human being, he now ungrudgingly admitted, was indeed a spirit of a higher order than any beast, though in the main obtuse, heartless, unfaithful to the best in himself.

fields.author: S. Baring-Gould, M.A.
fields.raw_text:
I noticed...that when they had swallowed a certain amount of information they held up their heads much like fowls after drinking.

—S. Baring-Gould, M.A. The Merewigs (contained in A Book of Ghosts) 1904
fields.text: I noticed...that when they had swallowed a certain amount of information they held up their heads much like fowls after drinking.
fields.source: The Merewigs (contained in A Book of Ghosts)

fields.author: Henri René Albert Guy de Maupassant
fields.raw_text:
She was one of those pretty and charming girls who are sometimes, as if by a mistake of destiny, born in a family of clerks.  She had no dowry, no expectations, no means of being known, understood, loved, wedded, by any rich and distinguished man; and she let herself be married to a little clerk at the Ministry of Public Instruction.

—Henri René Albert Guy de Maupassant The Necklace 1884
fields.text: She was one of those pretty and charming girls who are sometimes, as if by a mistake of destiny, born in a family of clerks.  She had no dowry, no expectations, no means of being known, understood, loved, wedded, by any rich and distinguished man; and she let herself be married to a little clerk at the Ministry of Public Instruction.

fields.author: Honoré de Balzac
fields.raw_text:
Yet nature has her freaks in the making of a man's mind; she indulges herself and makes a few honest folk now and again....

—Honoré de Balzac Melmoth Reconciled 1835
fields.text: Yet nature has her freaks in the making of a man's mind; she indulges herself and makes a few honest folk now and again....

fields.author: F. Marion Crawford
fields.raw_text:
If I were you, I would never tell ugly stories about ingenious ways of killing people, for you never can tell but that some one at the table may be tired of his or her nearest and dearest.

—F. Marion Crawford The Screaming Skull 1911
fields.text: If I were you, I would never tell ugly stories about ingenious ways of killing people, for you never can tell but that some one at the table may be tired of his or her nearest and dearest.

fields.author: F. Marion Crawford
fields.raw_text:
Whatever heaven may be, there is no earthly paradise without woman, nor is there anywhere a place so desolate, so dreary, so unutterably miserable that a woman cannot make it seem heaven to the man she loves, and who loves her.

—F. Marion Crawford By the Waters of Paradise 1894
fields.text: Whatever heaven may be, there is no earthly paradise without woman, nor is there anywhere a place so desolate, so dreary, so unutterably miserable that a woman cannot make it seem heaven to the man she loves, and who loves her.

fields.author: F. Marion Crawford
fields.raw_text:
Women are very like religion - we must take them on faith, or go without.

—F. Marion Crawford Doctor Claudius 1883
fields.text: Women are very like religion - we must take them on faith, or go without.

fields.author: F. Marion Crawford
fields.raw_text:
Very.  I sometimes buy a cheap copy and substitute the names of my pet enemies all through the Inferno wherever they will suit the foot.  In that way I get all the satisfaction the author got by putting his friends in hell, without the labor of writing, or the ability to compose, the poem.

—F. Marion Crawford Doctor Claudius 1883
fields.text: Very.  I sometimes buy a cheap copy and substitute the names of my pet enemies all through the Inferno wherever they will suit the foot.  In that way I get all the satisfaction the author got by putting his friends in hell, without the labor of writing, or the ability to compose, the poem.

fields.author: Alexander Pope
fields.raw_text:
He asks no angel's wing, no seraph's fire; But thinks admitted to that equal sky, His faithful dog shall bear him company.

—Alexander Pope Essay on Man 1734

In the depth of winter I finally learned that there was in me an invincible summer.

—Albert Camus 1913 - 1960

fields.author: Fun.: Bhasker, Ruess, Dost, Dough
fields.raw_text:
I try twice as hard and I'm half as liked....And that's alright.

—Fun.: Bhasker, Ruess, Dost, Dough Some Nights 2012
fields.text: I try twice as hard and I'm half as liked....And that's alright.

fields.author: Thomas Hardy
fields.raw_text:
Each time that she approached...they gazed at each other with smiles, and with that unmistakable expression which means so little at the moment, yet so often leads up to passion, heart-ache, union, disunion, devotion, overpopulation, drudgery, content, resignation, despair.

—Thomas Hardy On the Western Circuit 1891
fields.text: Each time that she approached...they gazed at each other with smiles, and with that unmistakable expression which means so little at the moment, yet so often leads up to passion, heart-ache, union, disunion, devotion, overpopulation, drudgery, content, resignation, despair.

fields.author: Edith Œnone Somerville & Martin Ross
fields.raw_text:
It was seven o'clock, the sun was setting, the sky was warming to its last loveliness of rose and amber, and amethyst, colours with names almost as beautiful as themselves.

—Edith Œnone Somerville & Martin Ross Mount Music 1919
fields.text: It was seven o'clock, the sun was setting, the sky was warming to its last loveliness of rose and amber, and amethyst, colours with names almost as beautiful as themselves.

fields.author: Maria Edgeworth
fields.raw_text:
Those who persecute, to overturn religion, can scarcely pretend to more philosophy, or more liberality, than those who persecute to support it.

—Maria Edgeworth Belinda 1800
fields.text: Those who persecute, to overturn religion, can scarcely pretend to more philosophy, or more liberality, than those who persecute to support it.

fields.author: Wilkie Collins
fields.raw_text:
Only give a woman love, and there is nothing she will not venture, suffer, and do.

—Wilkie Collins The Law and the Lady 1875
fields.text: Only give a woman love, and there is nothing she will not venture, suffer, and do.

fields.author: Arthur Gask
fields.raw_text:
The religion of kindness has no temples and no priests, but all the same it's not a bad faith to adhere to.

—Arthur Gask The Night of the Storm 1937
fields.text: The religion of kindness has no temples and no priests, but all the same it's not a bad faith to adhere to.

fields.author: Anthony Trollope
fields.raw_text:
...drudge don't sound so well.  Call her a ministering angel instead, and it comes to the same thing.

— Anthony Trollope The Struggles of Brown, Jones, and Robinson 1862
fields.text: ...drudge don't sound so well.  Call her a ministering angel instead, and it comes to the same thing.
fields.source: The Struggles of Brown, Jones, and Robinson

fields.author: Anthony Trollope
fields.raw_text:
You're that green that the very cows would eat you.

—Anthony Trollope The Struggles of Brown, Jones, and Robinson 1862
fields.text: You're that green that the very cows would eat you.
fields.source: The Struggles of Brown, Jones, and Robinson

fields.author: Margaret Mitchell
fields.raw_text:
...the terrible strength of the weak, the gentle, the tender hearted.

—Margaret Mitchell Gone with the Wind 1936
fields.text: ...the terrible strength of the weak, the gentle, the tender hearted.

fields.author: Edgar Wallace
fields.raw_text:
There is nothing quite as effective as a noticeable rotundity for reducing the conscious ego.

—Edgar Wallace The Cat Burglar and Other Stories 1929
fields.text: There is nothing quite as effective as a noticeable rotundity for reducing the conscious ego.
fields.source: The Cat Burglar and Other Stories

fields.author: Josephine Tey
fields.raw_text:
Hate is very lowering, isn't it...?

—Josephine Tey A Shilling for Candles 1936
fields.text: Hate is very lowering, isn't it...?

fields.author: Anne Brontë
fields.raw_text:
But...still it is only a child; and I can't centre all my hopes in a child: that is only one degree better than devoting oneself to a dog.

—Anne Brontë Agnes Grey 1847
fields.text: But...still it is only a child; and I can't centre all my hopes in a child: that is only one degree better than devoting oneself to a dog.

fields.author: Edgar Wallace
fields.raw_text:
Marriage destroys the icing, but reveals the cake, and you can't live on almond icing any more than you can make a square meal of Turkish Delight.

—Edgar Wallace Circumstantial Evidence and Other Stories 1934
fields.text: Marriage destroys the icing, but reveals the cake, and you can't live on almond icing any more than you can make a square meal of Turkish Delight.

fields.author: George MacDonald
fields.raw_text:
To have what we want is riches, but to be able to do without is power.

—George MacDonald Donal Grant 1883
fields.text: To have what we want is riches, but to be able to do without is power.

fields.author: Walt Whitman
fields.raw_text:
Happiness,...not in another place but this place, not for another hour but this hour.

—Walt Whitman Chants Democratic 1871
fields.text: Happiness,...not in another place but this place, not for another hour but this hour.

fields.author: Agatha Christie
fields.raw_text:
"I don't often do much thinking," said Rosamund. "It seems a waste of time."

—Agatha Christie After the Funeral 1953
fields.text: "I don't often do much thinking," said Rosamund. "It seems a waste of time."

fields.author: Grant Allen
fields.raw_text:
Life was not given us to waste on gratuitous martyrdoms.

—Grant Allen Hilda Wade 1899
fields.text: Life was not given us to waste on gratuitous martyrdoms.

fields.author: Thorne Smith
fields.raw_text:
The seal of sin is settling on [his] brow.  He looks healthier and less uninteresting.

—Thorne Smith The Jovial Ghosts:  The Misadventures of Topper 1926
fields.text: The seal of sin is settling on [his] brow.  He looks healthier and less uninteresting.
fields.source: The Jovial Ghosts:  The Misadventures of Topper

fields.author: E. Phillips Oppenheim
fields.raw_text:
...art simply represents man's passionate desire to drag the truth out of life in half a dozen different ways.  God does it for you in the country!

—E. Phillips Oppenheim The Hillman 1917
fields.text: ...art simply represents man's passionate desire to drag the truth out of life in half a dozen different ways.  God does it for you in the country!

fields.author: Melissa McCarthy
fields.raw_text:
[In your 20's] You're like, "I'm so embarrassed I don't have a new shirt for tonight."  By the time you're 44, it's like, "If this is marginally clean, I'm good."

—Melissa McCarthy People Magazine July 7, 2014
fields.text: [In your 20's] You're like, "I'm so embarrassed I don't have a new shirt for tonight."  By the time you're 44, it's like, "If this is marginally clean, I'm good."

fields.author: Willa Cather
fields.raw_text:
There are some things you learn best in calm, and some in storm.

—Willa Cather The Song of the Lark 1915
fields.text: There are some things you learn best in calm, and some in storm.

fields.author: F. Marion Crawford
fields.raw_text:
Only in his simple heart he would like to know in so many words what the commands were; and that is sometimes a little hard, for women like to be half understood before they speak, and the grosser intellect of man seldom more than half understands them after they have spoken.

—F. Marion Crawford Doctor Claudius 1883
fields.text: Only in his simple heart he would like to know in so many words what the commands were; and that is sometimes a little hard, for women like to be half understood before they speak, and the grosser intellect of man seldom more than half understands them after they have spoken.

fields.author: George MacDonald
fields.raw_text:
It seems to me...that the cause of discomfort and strife is never that we are too near others, but that we are not near enough.

—George MacDonald Donal Grant 1883
fields.text: It seems to me...that the cause of discomfort and strife is never that we are too near others, but that we are not near enough.

fields.author: Sapper (H.C. McNeile)
fields.raw_text:
I do not look at my face more often than necessary as a general rule, it shakes me too badly to see it.

—Sapper (H.C. McNeile) The Female of the Species 1928
fields.text: I do not look at my face more often than necessary as a general rule, it shakes me too badly to see it.

fields.author: M.P. Shiel
fields.raw_text:
For men stand, as it were, at different heights, each seeing from his own level, so what the beggar thinks is heaven, the millionaire regards as nothing and what the millionaire pursues, the saint or the thinker regards as a bauble.

—M.P. Shiel The Evil That Men Do 1904
fields.text: For men stand, as it were, at different heights, each seeing from his own level, so what the beggar thinks is heaven, the millionaire regards as nothing and what the millionaire pursues, the saint or the thinker regards as a bauble.

fields.raw_text:
Autumn is a second spring when every leaf is a flower.

—Albert Camus

1913-1960

fields.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
fields.raw_text:
...for every one in the town was ready to look after her as being an idiot, and so specially dear to God.

—Fyodor Dostoevsky The Brothers Karamazov 1880
fields.text: ...for every one in the town was ready to look after her as being an idiot, and so specially dear to God.

fields.author: Ambrose Bierce
fields.raw_text:
Belladonna, n.: In Italian a beautiful lady; in English, a deadly poison.  A striking example of the essential identity of the two tongues.

—Ambrose Bierce The Devil's Dictionary 1911
fields.text: Belladonna, n.: In Italian a beautiful lady; in English, a deadly poison.  A striking example of the essential identity of the two tongues.
